Breastfeeding is a natural phenomenon. It is a safe and the best method of providing any baby with all that are required for proper growth and development. It is a physiological process that ensures the provision of adequate nourishment, warmth and protection to the baby. The act of breastfeeding is not only beneficial to the child; but also to the mother, father, the community and the nation at large. Although breastfeeding is a natural process, it is also a learned behavior that requires a deliberate intention of the mother.

Though most women are aware of breastfeeding and do breastfeed, yet the practice is often below the require standard (suboptimum). Assumption and cultural beliefs are also found to mitigate against the appropriateness of breastfeeding. Breastfeeding should be considered as a responsibility and not a burden as commonly viewed by most mothers in order to ensure adequate growth, development and survival of every child.

Breastfeeding cannot be achieved successfully without adequate care and support. Supports can be rendered first by the father of the baby, then grandmother and/or mother-in-law, respected family members or relatives, health workers, and even the community. Government can also provide support through appropriate policies that support the breastfeeding practice. Though breastfeeding is tasking yet irrespective of the level of support, it should be enjoyed and not endured by mothers.

To ensure optimum breastfeeding practices, there is therefore the need for the mothers to know and understand the fundamentals of breastfeeding which include; the “what”, “why”, “how” and “when” of breastfeeding. Understanding the significance and involvement of relevant and interested parties in breastfeeding can boost the confidence of mothers towards breastfeeding and ultimately lead to healthy living of both the mother and child as a result of optimum breastfeeding practice.

Breast milk production involve the action of hormones and reflexes. It require physiological, psychological and nutritional preparations right from conception to the delivery of the child. It is important that pregnant women are conversant with the tenets of breastfeeding, have adequate breastfeeding knowledge, have a strong conviction and built confidence that they can and will breastfeed.

Adequate nutrition for mothers before, during and after pregnancy is essential to achieve successful breastfeeding. All the ingredients required by mothers to breastfeed come from their nutrient reserve accrued during pregnancy and adequacy of food intake after delivery.

During pregnancy, hormonal changes occur to prepare the gland tissues in the breast to secrete milk; followed by series of changes after delivery that subsequently leads to the production and release of milk from the breast.

• Breast milk is secreted/produced by the breast cells with help of a hormone called prolactin.
 • This hormone which is produced at the anterior part of the pituitary gland of the brain is responsible for the secretion of milk by the breast cells in the breast.
 • To ensure the delivery of the breast milk to the baby, the baby must first be attached properly to the breast by the mother.
 • Each time the baby’s mouth is attached to the breast the signal transmitters are stimulated and then send signal message to the anterior part of the pituitary gland of the brain to release prolactin hormone.
 o Proper attachment means the baby’s mouth covering the black region around the nipple (areola).
 • Another hormone involved in milk production is oxytocin, also located in the pituitary gland but in the posterior end. This hormone ensures the release or ejection of the secreted milk from the breast cells through the nipple.
 • As the baby suckles (remained attached to the breast), more milk will be secreted and hence released to the baby’s mouth. Therefore the more the baby sucked, the more the secreted breast milk and its release

Certain factors have been established to either enhance or hinder the release of the secreted milk through the oxytocin activities. Few of such factors are;

 • Mother’s love for the baby.
 • Baby’s cry.
 • Mother’s worries, anxiety or doubt to breastfeed.
 • Improper breastfeeding positioning.
 • Lack of adequate care and support for mothers.
The human breast milk contains all the nutrients in the right proportion needed by the baby for growth and development especially in the first six months of life.

Breast milk has both nutrients and non-nutrients components. The nutrients constituents include those that serve as source of energy (macronutrients) such as fats, carbohydrates (mainly lactose) and proteins. Others are the micronutrients-which are basically vitamins and minerals. The non-nutrient components of breast milk include; digestive enzymes, anti-microbial and anti-inflammatory agents, hormones, growth factors, trophic factors and nucleotides. The non-nutritional constituents basically help the baby to adapt to oral feeding by promoting mucosal defense and functions as well as aiding digestion until the baby’s gastrointestinal tract is fully developed. Many of these nutritional and non-nutritional substances are involved in many of the short –and long-term effects breastfeeding has on the babies.

Human milk is different from cow milk in all its components therefore cow milk should not serve as a replacement for human milk. Human breast is designed by nature to feed human offspring. The deliberate attempt of some mothers in averting from nurture by nature to total dependence on animal or artificial means of nurturing their children has both short and long term negative consequence.

If at all there is any reason why mothers should breastfeed; it should be attributed to the fact that breastfeeding is a universally acceptable practice for all mothers, and that its recommendation and promotion is supported by global health bodies such as World Health Organization (WHO), United Nation Children Fund (UNICEF) as well as research institutions.

Benefits to the child
 • Breastfeeding is the most safe and clean mode of child feeding therefore breastfed babies are less prone to infections.
 • Breastfeeding reduces the incidence and duration of diarrhoea.
 • Breast milk contains antibodies that enhance the immune system of the baby hence serve as a personalized medicine for baby.
 • Breast milk is easily digested, absorbed and utilized by the baby’s body hence making it adequate in the provision of nourishment.
 • Less workload are given to the immature kidneys of the breastfed babies.
 • Breastfeeding protects babies against food allergies especially in their early life.
 • Breastfeeding enhance proper cognitive development of the child thereby ensure higher academic performance.
 • Breastfeeding promotes better jaw shape and development teeth.
 • It also protect the baby from dental disorders.
 • Breastfed children have lower risk of childhood overweight and obesity (and diabetes in later life) as it provide nutrients their right quantity and quality.
 • Breastfeeding promote bonding between mother and child.
 • Childhood cancers are less common among breastfed children compared to predominantly formula-fed children.
 • Breastfeeding lowers the risk of asthma and other respiratory disorders.

Benefits to the Mother
 • Breastfeeding helps in contraction of the uterus back to its pre-pregnancy state.
 • Breastfeeding reduces bleeding after delivery (postpartum haemorrhage).
 • In most women but not all, breastfeeding prevent the mother from getting pregnant during breastfeeding period (lactation amenorrhea).
 • Mothers who breastfeed their babies have reduced risk of breast and ovarian cancer.
 • Breastfeeding enhances mothers’ confidence in her maternal role.
 • Breastfeeding helps in preserving maternal iron store thus leading to improved iron status.
 • Breastfeeding assists mothers in the shedding of excess weight gained during pregnancy.
 • Breastfeeding creates an attachment/bond between the mother and her child thereby protecting the child from strangers.
 • Breastfeeding improves bone mineralization thereby reduce the risk of osteoporosis.

Benefits to the family/society
 • Breast milk is natural, readily available and free hence requires no extra cost compare to the purchase of infant formula.
 • Long term benefit of breastfeeding ensures increase in productivity of the family and the nation at large.
 • Breastfeeding reduces the risk and prevalence of childhood death.
 • Breast milk is a natural renewable food that is environmentally safe, produced and delivered to consumers without pollution, unnecessary packaging or waste.
 • Poor cognitive development due suboptimum breastfeeding affect intelligence, adult earnings and national productivity.
 • Breastfeeding helps in child spacing, population control hence ensure effective distribution and utilization of resources.

It is necessary for early initiation to be established for all babies by ensuring that they are put to breast within the first hour of delivery. This practice helps the mother and the baby to get along with breastfeeding as early as possible.\n\n
Babies born through vaginal delivery and caesarean section (CS) should not be separated from the mother immediately after birth. They should be placed in the mother’s arm on chest to allow rooming-in and keep the baby warm. Rooming-in helps the baby to reach the breast and feel close to the mother early. This practice encourages early initiation of breastfeeding which in turn allow the baby to feed on colostrum.

Colostrum is the first yellowish and thick milk secreted after a baby had been delivered. Its production is usually in late pregnancy to about the third day after birth. It is regarded as the first immunization for the baby due its richness in antibodies and white blood cells. It is also rich in whey protein and vitamin A. Colostrum helps to protect the baby against almost early infections that the baby is exposed to. It also it helps the baby to produce its first stool (meconium).\n\n
The colostrum produced is enough to satisfy the baby’s hunger and also prevent dehydration before the commencement of mothers’ secretion and release of the matured milk.

Prelacteal feeds are foods such as infant formula, animal milk, glucose, ORS and even water given to the baby in the first three days of life. The introduction of this feeds is discouraged as it negates breastfeeding initiation and inhibits optimum early breastfeeding practices.\n\n
Although some women especially first-time mothers may have delay in their secretion of breast milk; they should be encouraged to sustain attachment of the baby to the breast. It is worthy of note that while waiting for the release of the breast milk, water or any other liquid should not be given to the baby; instead the baby should be allowed to suckle at the mother’s breast as this will enhance the production of milk.

Prelacteal feeds should not be allowed because they can pose the following dangers to the baby’s health;

 • Diarrhoea.
 • Allergies.
 • Low level of milk secretion as the baby do not suckle on the mother’s breast.
 • Engorgement and mastitis may occur in the mother’s breast because the baby does not suckle to remove the milk secreted.
 • Possibility of breast milk refusal by the baby due to the alteration of the baby’s taste bud.
 • Increase risk of breastfeeding failure.

Breastfeeding should be on the baby’s demand and not schedule by the mother. Breastfeeding should be done on demand both during the day and at night. Number of feeding sessions varies with baby’s individual demand but it should not be less than 8 times in a day.\n\n Increased breastfeeding session ensure adequate delivery of nutrients from the breast milk to the baby, helps to improve the mother’s milk supply because more suckling with good attachment ensures adequate production of more milk.

It is important for mothers to feed the baby with one breast long enough (at least 15 minutes) before switching to the second breast. The implication is to allow the baby to get nourishment from both the fore milk and hind milk.\n\n
The fore milk is the milk produced in the few minutes (5-10 minutes) of breastfeeding. It is light (watery), rich in lactose and low in fat. Some vitamins are also found in the foremilk. Foremilk basically satisfy the baby’s thirst due to its high water content.

The hind milk comes after the foremilk. It is usually produced at about 10-15 minutes after the commencement of feeding session. It is usually dense and rich in fat, therefore energy dense. It basically satisfies the baby’s hunger.\n\n
In other to ensure that the baby gets both the foremilk and hind milk from a breast, the baby should not be fed less than 15 minutes hence each breastfeeding session with both breast should not be below 30 minutes.
Breastfeeding in the first six months
2) Why should mothers practice exclusive breastfeeding?

From the day of delivery to 6 months, a child is not to be given any other food or liquid except breast milk. This practice is known as exclusive breastfeeding.


Exclusive breastfeeding is a global recommended practice that involves feeding the baby with only breast milk for the first 6 months without other feed or water except medications recommended by medical personnel when required.


A well-nourished mother has the ability to provide sufficient milk to breastfeed her baby to satiety without additional breast substitutes until the child is six month old.

Although some mothers believe that breast milk only is not sufficient for any child. This is not right as researches has consistently shown that the nutrient composition of the breast milk is adequate enough both in quantity and quality to meet all the nutritional requirements of a baby up till 6 months.


Some mothers are also of the opinion that water is inevitable for the baby. This claim should be discarded as water constitutes 85-90% of breast milk.


Complimentary feeding is afterwards introduced from 6 months when breast milk is no longer sufficient to meet the baby’s daily energy and nutrient requirements.

Complementary feeding is not a replacement to breastfeeding. Complementary foods are given in addition to the supply from breast milk.


Some believe that exclusively breastfed babies are likely refuse complementary food from 6 months. This is not true because the technique that guide the introduction of complementary food is such that;

 • The baby gets almost all nutrients from breast milk but gradually starts other foods (semi-solid) prepared to be similar to the density of the breast milk.
 • The child continues to get same amount of breast milk but gets increasing amount of other foods which slowly increased in density (soft).
 • The child slowly deceases the amount of breast milk and eat increasing amount of family foods. This continues until breastfeeding cessation.

1. Exclusive breastfeeding protect the baby from illness due to contamination through other form of feeding (mixed feeding, replacement feeding etc).
 2. Mixed feeding before 6 month can harm the baby’s stomach as the digestive system is not fully developed.
 3. There is increased risk of malnutrition as the baby might not be meeting up to the daily nutrient requirement.
 4. Exclusive breastfeeding strengthens the mother-child bond.
 5. Exclusively breastfed babies have little hospital visit (except for immunization) hence reduces stress on the mothers and family as a whole.
 6. Exclusive breastfeeding prevent unnecessary spending on hospital bills and medications.

How often should I breastfeed?
Are feeding intervals counted from the time my baby starts or stops nursing?
Does breastfeeding hurt?
How do I know my baby\'s getting enough milk?
Can I breastfeed without exposing myself?
What\'s in it for me?
Can I breastfeed if I\'m not large breasted?
Won\'t I have to give up eating the foods I enjoy?
Doesn\'t breastfeeding tie you down?
How long does it take to breastfeed?
What\'s so special about human milk?
Why do people say breastfeeding is important?
Why bother breastfeeding when I know I\'ll be returning to work (or school)?
Will I be able to satisfy my baby?
What about the baby\'s father? Won\'t he feel left out if he can\'t feed the baby?
What if I have questions or need help?
Won\'t the baby bite me?

string-array.name: faq_answers
string-array.item:
Breastmilk is the normal food for babies, designed by nature for human infants:

•It is a complete food containing all your baby's nutritional needs for the first 6 months of life.
 •It satisfies both hunger and thirst; extra water is not needed.
 •It increases a baby's resistance to infection and disease.


Breastfeeding is important for mothers too.

•It's convenient, cheap and always there when you need it.
 •It's always fresh, clean and safe.
 •It quickly soothes a fussy, unhappy baby.
 •It helps your uterus return to its normal size after childbirth.
 •It gives you a chance to sit down during the day and rest.
 •Mothers who don't breastfeed have increased risks of cancer of the breast and ovaries.
 •Breastfeeding helps create a close and loving bond between you and your baby and can be a deeply satisfying experience for you both.
Most babies have a strong need to suck when they are first born, so if you are both well you can start straight away. The first milk in your breasts is called colostrum.

Your baby is hard-wired to find her way to your breast. If you hold your baby skin-to-skin on your chest, between your breasts, and wait a little while, you are likely to find that she attaches to feed all by herself. More information on baby-led attachment can be found here.

If you prefer to help your baby to attach, hold your baby close to you, chest to chest and chin to breast with your nipple opposite baby's mouth. Gently touch baby's lips with your nipple to encourage your baby's mouth to open wide. Make sure that your nipple and as much as possible of your areola (the darker area around your nipple) is in baby's mouth.

No matter what technique you use, when baby is positioned correctly for breastfeeding, it should not hurt you. Initial tenderness is normal. If you feel any nipple pain, seek help. For example by calling an ABA breastfeeding counsellor or seeing a lactation consultant.

Your breasts make milk in response to your baby's sucking. The more milk the baby takes, the more milk you make.

You will establish a good supply of milk if you:

•Breastfeed frequently, whenever your baby fusses or seems hungry.
 •Let baby finish the first breast. You will know this because the baby will stop sucking and swallowing and will let go of the breast. Then offer the second breast.
 •Breastfeed your baby at night. This also helps prevent your breasts becoming too full and uncomfortable.
 •Many young babies feed between 8-12 times in 24 hours.
 •Avoid giving complementary bottles ('comps'), as these will reduce your baby's needs to suck at the breast and so reduce your supply.

Your milk will flow more easily if you are relaxed and comfortable at feed times. This is not always easy in those early days when everything is new and strange and you and your baby are still getting to know each other.
 
 The following hints may help:
 •Cuddle your baby close to you, skin-to-skin, before offering the breast
 •If your baby is too sleepy to feed and you are taking medications, ask your doctor if they could be affecting your baby
 •Talk to your doctor if pain from stitches is making you tense
 •Draw the curtains if you feel you would like privacy in hospital
 •Breathing slowly and deeply may help you relax
 •Gently massaging your breasts and rolling your nipples between your thumb and forefinger before putting baby to the breast may start your milk flowing.


Remember, a baby's tummy is tiny so he will need to breastfeed little and often.

You know your baby is getting enough breastmilk if she:

•Is breastfeeding well and frequently
 •Has plenty of pale, wet nappies (at least 5 disposable or 6-8 cloth nappies in 24 hours)
 •Has 3 or more soft bowel motions a day (babies older than around 6 weeks may have less than this)
 •Is gaining weight and has some periods in which she seems reasonably alert, active and happy.

If you feel your supply is low:
•Breastfeed your baby more often
 •Take things easy for a few days
 •Relax and hold your baby skin-to-skin to encourage him to feed more often.


The more milk your baby takes from your breasts, the more milk you will make. It will take a week or longer of more frequent feeds to see a real increase in milk supply.

There are no magic foods that will increase the milk supply. A sensible balanced diet is the key. You also do not need to avoid any particular foods. The most recent research suggests that excluding allergenic foods from a mother\'s diet during pregnancy or breastfeeding does not help prevent babies from developing allergies. Also see the Diet and weight loss while breastfeeding article on this website.

New babies wake at night from hunger and need to be breastfed. This also helps your milk supply. Some babies sleep through the night quite early while others take much longer to do so. Breastfeeding is a quick and easy way to soothe and settle your baby.

More and more women are able to combine breastfeeding and working in the paid work force. There are lots of helpful articles on this topic available here. You may also like to read ABA\'s booklet, Breastfeeding: women and work, which is available for purchase from the Australian Breastfeeding Association by calling 03 9885 0855 or emailing officemanager@breastfeeding.asn.au.
ask us for help

If your baby tends to suck on the tip of your nipple, without getting much of your areola, he or she is latched on incorrectly. Babies who tend to latch on wrong also fall sleep at the breast more often and may not seem satisfied because they may not be getting enough. If this happens, break the suction and reposition your baby onto your breast to include the nipple and areola.
Call your doctor or a lactation consultant if:
you\'re unable to nurse your baby without pain (you may just need help getting your baby to latch on correctly, or it could be a sign of a nipple injury or breast infection) your baby consistently sleeps at the breast your baby is nursing but doesn\'t seem satisfied when feedings are over your baby does not gain weight as expected or does not produce the usual numbers of wet and soiled diapers (about 6 wet and 4 soiled each day at first)

Once a baby is latched onto the breast, he or she usually takes four to five sucks, followed by a 5- to 10-second pause. Your baby\'s sucks will increase in number as the quantity of your milk increases. As the milk flow slows, your baby\'s pattern will probably change to three or four sucks and pauses that last longer than 10 seconds.
Most babies will release the breast on their own. If your baby doesn\'t release your breast but the sucks now seem limited to the front of his or her mouth, slip your finger in the side of your baby\'s mouth (between the gums) and then turn your finger a quarter turn to break the suction. Then, try to burp your baby and switch him or her to the other breast.
Newborns will often fall asleep while breastfeeding. If this happens, try to wake your baby by tickling the feet, rubbing the back, or taking off some clothing. Sometimes burping your baby or changing the diaper also can be helpful.

Your newborn should be nursing 8-12 times per day for about the first month. If you feel like you\'re feeding your little one more often than a friend whose baby is formula fed, you might be. Why? Because breast milk digests easier than formula, which means it moves through your baby\'s digestive system faster and, therefore, your baby is hungry more often. Frequent feedings also will help stimulate your milk production during the first few weeks. By 1 to 2 months of age, a breastfed baby will probably nurse 7-9 times a day. Before your milk supply is established, breastfeeding should be "on demand" (when your baby is hungry), which is generally every 1½ to 3 hours. As newborns get older, they\'ll nurse less often, and may develop a more reliable schedule. Some might feed every 90 minutes, whereas others might go 2 or 3 hours between feedings. Newborns should not go more than about 4 hours without feeding, even overnight.

You count the length between feedings from the time when your baby begins to nurse — rather than when he or she ends — to when your little one starts nursing again. In other words, when your doctor asks how often your baby is feeding, you can say "about every 2 hours" if your first feeding started at 6 a.m. and the next feeding was at around 8 a.m., then 10 a.m., and so on.
This means that, especially at first, you may feel like you\'re nursing around the clock, which is completely normal. Soon enough, you\'ll both be on a more routine, predictable schedule.
NO! If it does, there\'s something wrong with the way the baby is latched on. Take him off and begin again.

Once the milk comes in, the theory of "what-goes-in-one-end-comes-out-the-other" works: 4-6 wet disposable diapers (6-8 cloth) and 3-4 bowel movements in 24 hours usually indicate the baby is getting an adequate volume of your milk.

Absolutely! Besides special clothing available expressly for discreet nursing, wearing a two-piece outfit and pulling the shirt up from the waist works well. Drape a burp cloth or receiving blanket over your shoulder for greater coverage! Practice nursing in front of a mirror until you are comfortable that nothing shows that shouldn\'t!

A smarter, healthier baby who is less likely to be allergic. Less chance of breast, ovarian and cervical cancers. Getting back in shape faster. A wonderful, enduring bond with your baby. So easy -- nothing to fix, buy or clean.
Yes! Size has nothing to do with milk production. Changes in the breast during early pregnancy make it possible for the breasts to make milk.

Not at all. Just eat a well-balanced diet, and you may wish to continue taking your prenatal vitamins while breastfeeding. Only if the baby\'s father has a severe allergy to certain food(s) should you eliminate these from your -- and your baby\'s -- diet.

Not really. During the first few months, a breastfed baby is very portable! Just pack a few extra diapers and maybe a change of clothes for the baby and you\'re ready to leave! Later, you may want to express or pump some of your special milk to leave for your baby while you\'re away.

Soon after the baby is born, feedings usually take 15-20 minutes per side and most mothers offer both sides at each feeding. If the baby falls asleep, start the next feeding with the breast that didn\'t get nursed at the last feeding. Later, as the baby becomes more efficient, an entire feeding may only take 10-15 minutes!

Your body makes it especially for your baby. Cow\'s milk was designed for baby calves! Every time your baby nurses, he gets protection from exactly what you and he have come in contact with. Plus exactly what he needs for brain development and perfect growth.

At birth, a baby is immune to everything his mother is but has no functional immune system of his own, until at 6 weeks the faint stirrings begin. By the time the baby is 6 months old, he will have a functional, but still immature, immune system to help keep him healthy and allergy free. Breastmilk gives the baby all the immunities he needs until he can make his own.

Once you return to school or work, you could either pump your milk for your baby to use the next day or choose to give him bottles while you\'re away. Although you might need to pump for a few days until your breasts don\'t feel so full anymore, your body will adjust just as it will when the baby sleeps through the night

The human breast is designed to refill the milk that is used: the policy of supply and demand. Before bottles were so prevalent, we all assumed that every mother would feed her own baby and there were no worries about this! Allowing the baby to nurse until he stops every 2-3 hours in the beginning will assure that you will make enough milk.

There are lots of things fathers can do with a baby besides feeding him. Bathing provides lots of skin-to-skin contact and fun, too! Sitting by you while you nurse the baby and rubbing between your shoulder blades usually gives the baby a milk mustache! Listen for the rapid swallowing! Rocking, holding, cuddling and playing with the baby will make dad feel a part of the action.
Call your local La Leche League Leader! If she doesn\'t know, she can find out for you.
When a baby is properly nursing, he will first bite his own tongue! Teeth usually do not appear until the baby is 5-6 months old, and by then you will be alert to his cues.
